title: Lab to determine g using a pulley with inertia

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown above. They are expected to find <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown above, which includes a two-block system with masses <math alttext="M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="M sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, a very light string, and a uniform disk-shaped pulley with mass <math alttext="M sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. There is a peg on top of each of the blocks where additional masses can be placed, if necessary. There is negligible friction between block <math alttext="M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the table. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown above. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown above, which includes a two-block system with masses <math alttext="M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="M sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, a very light string, and a uniform disk-shaped pulley with mass <math alttext="M sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. There is a peg on top of each of the blocks where additional masses can be placed, if necessary. There is negligible friction between block <math alttext="M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the table. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a).

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) In a second experiment, the students replace the pulley with another one with the same mass <math alttext="M sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The mass of the new pulley is more concentrated at its center and less dense towards its outer edge. Is the magnitude of the tension in the vertical section of this string larger than, smaller than, or equal to the magnitude of the tension in the same section of string in the initial experiment?
